g.title: leaf_21
g.text: I've been thinking about how to approach existing codebases.

g.title: leaf_23
g.text: The simplest approach is to have one page per file, and interiorize the whole
thing. But that gets messy if you're trying to upstream changes.

g.title: leaf_25
g.text: I want something more like this:

g.title: leaf_31
g.text: Splice is a specialization, we'd usually put it in a drawer:

g.title: leaf_41
g.text: line references are to the original file, such that deletions and additions
in a single pass don't affect one another's offset.

g.title: leaf_43
g.text: The subtle bit is turning a transclusion into a splice. Normally edits in a
transclusion are either shared with source (the default) or are isolated in
the document, call that an exerpt maybe.

g.title: leaf_45
g.text: In a splice, edits to the transclusion are mirrored in the sorcery file, but
in a way that the splicing document is blind to.

g.title: leaf_47
g.text: Splices are slightly delicate and might need to be manually adjusted if an
upstream pushes large changes. They'll be pretty useful in practice.

g.title: leaf_49
g.text: This lets me unleash the full might of Orb on codebases such as LuaJIT, where
trying to hoover the whole thing into a literate translation would be a lot of
work, and hostile to the goal of getting change sets onto master.

g.title: leaf_51
g.text: A splice can be turned back into an ordinary transclusion. The difference is
that working on a file in splice mode is archaeological. Any of the changes
can be unapplied, so we can go nuts on other people's code and still offer a
tasteful, minimal patch set, without getting involved in cherry-picking.

g.title: leaf_53
g.text: Even within our own codebases, splices may work better than the more
traditional literate macro for conditional compilation and the like.
